column4: can someone tell me how to open a file in the terminal, say a pascal code file, so i can run it on the terminal?
it brought up some nano thing but what does that do and how do i use it?
but isnt there a way to just run it through the terminal
i've seen it done b4 but cant remember how
huh???
so it tells me if it's working or not, compile it
you seem to be confused.  a file such as you mentioned is a source code file for a programming language.  You can change it with an editor, and of course you can compile it, and then run it.
you may be thinking of an IDE, which is a program that wraps an editor, and compiler, and such into an easy to use interface
you can use, say, emacs, or vim, both of which allow you to compile from within the editor
it's the "it" that is in question here, not whether it can be done from a terminal
as I said, both vim and emacs allow you to edit, compile, and run, from a terminal session
those are the ones that come to mind in this environment
most IDEs are GUI only; vim and emacs are the only ones I can think of, at the moment, that do what you are saying from a terminal
you can run the compiler from the command line, sure, and then run the compiled program.
is that what you mean?
what's compilcated?  I told you, emacs and vim can both do what you are asking.
so?  you can't manage to type:    emacs filename?
or,   vim filename?
no such thing
nothing is "built in".  some things are installed by default.
indeed, I do.
since I know and you don't.
well, since you obviously know people who are so much smarter than we are, why don't you go talk to one of them?
well, since we are all so inadequate, I guess you'll have to wait until he's on line.
